title: Summon
data:
***Version [0.31](/0.31 "0.31")**: This article **may not be** up to date for the [latest stable release](/0.32 "0.32") of Crawl.*

|   |                                                                                                                                   |
| - | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
|   | This monster has been summoned, and is thus temporary. Killing it yields no experience or items; it is incapable of using stairs. |

**Summons** are creatures bound by magical forces, most often created by the [Summonings](/Summonings "Summonings") school of spells. For the most part, summoned monsters function much like real monsters, with the following exceptions:

- They are worth no experience or piety, and leave nothing behind when slain.

- [Vampiric](/Vampiric "Vampiric") weapons and [Vampiric Draining](/Vampiric_Draining "Vampiric Draining") don't work on them.

- They eventually "time out" regardless of their [HP](/HP "HP"), vanishing in a cloud of smoke.

  - Summoned monsters immediately vanish upon the death of their summoner.
  - Most player summons will vanish if angered.
  - They are vulnerable to [abjuration](/Abjuration "Abjuration") and [Yara's Violent Unravelling](/Yara%27s_Violent_Unravelling "Yara's Violent Unravelling").

- They will not follow you up or down [stairs](/Stairs "Stairs"). This allows you to flee hostile summoned units and return after sufficient time has passed. Your own summoned allies will disappear immediately when you change floors.

- Allied summons will not attack monsters outside of the player's [line of sight](/Line_of_sight "Line of sight").

### Duration

Summoned monsters are generated with a duration between 1 and 6. This value roughly corresponds to the following amount in [auts](/Aut "Aut") (arbitrary units of time; 10 aut = 1 "turn"):[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

1. 90 aut
2. 180 aut
3. 270 aut
4. 360 aut
5. 810 aut
6. 1710 aut

Some Summonings spells have a fixed duration. Other spells increase duration with power (spellpower, [piety](/Piety "Piety"), etc.).

### Summon Limit

Most Summonings spells have [a cap on how many monsters](/Summoning#Summoning_Limits "Summoning") you can sustain at any one time; exceeding the limit will cause the oldest monsters to time out almost immediately. Other sources of summons, like [gods](/God "God"), [evocables](/Evocable "Evocable"), and the [scroll of summoning](/Scroll_of_summoning "Scroll of summoning"), are unaffected.

## Durable Summon

|   |                                                                                                                                                 |
| - | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
|   | This monster has been summoned in a durable way, and only partially exists. Killing it yields no experience or items, and it cannot be abjured. |

A **durable summon**, or monster that is **durably summoned**, is similar to a summoned monster with a few notable exceptions:

- They never disappear.
- They are not vulnerable to [abjuration](/Abjuration "Abjuration") or [Yara's Violent Unravelling](/Yara%27s_Violent_Unravelling "Yara's Violent Unravelling").
- They will follow you up or down stairs.
- They *can* be targeted by Vampiric Draining.

Durable summons are most often used as punishments for the player; whenever from the [divine retribution](/Divine_retribution "Divine retribution") of several [gods](/God "God"), or [nameless horrors](/Nameless_horror "Nameless horror") from [miscast](/Miscast "Miscast") Summonings spells.

## Non-Summons

The following effects are not summoned, despite sharing similarities:

- [Malign Gateway](/Malign_Gateway "Malign Gateway"), which is immune to abjuration and will turn hostile over time. This is the only [Summonings](/Summonings "Summonings") spell that doesn't create an actual summon.
- [Derived undead](/Derived_undead "Derived undead"), created by [Necromancy](/Necromancy "Necromancy"). They are still temporary when created by the player, vanishing if you enter another floor.
- [Hornets](/Hornet "Hornet") from a [shambling mangrove](/Shambling_mangrove "Shambling mangrove") or reinforcements from a [doom hound](/Doom_hound "Doom hound"), which are completely non-summons and worth XP and piety as usual.

## History

- Prior to [0.29](/0.29 "0.29"), [Uskayaw](/Uskayaw "Uskayaw") did not give piety for harming summoned monsters.
- Prior to [0.28](/0.28 "0.28"), summoned monsters would steal [XP](/XP "XP") proportional to their damage dealt (1/2 XP if you did no damage)
- Prior to [0.25](/0.25 "0.25"), non-durable summons could not be affected by [Inner Flame](/Inner_Flame "Inner Flame"). In addition, most player-summoned creatures didn't vanish when they became hostile.
- Prior to [0.19](/0.19 "0.19"), the [mercenary card](/Mercenary_card "Mercenary card") would create allied durable summons.
- Prior to [0.18](/0.18 "0.18"), the [warding](/Warding "Warding") intrinsic existed to counter (non durable) summons.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [mon-ench.cc:2381](https://github.com/crawl/crawl/blob/0.31.0/crawl-ref/source/mon-ench.cc#L2381) (0.31.0)

This monster has been summoned, and is thus temporary. Killing it yields no experience or items; it is incapable of using stairs.

Summons are creatures bound by magical forces, most often created by the Summonings school of spells. For the most part, summoned monsters function much like real monsters, with the following exceptions:

  • They are worth no experience or piety, and leave nothing behind when slain.
  • Vampiric weapons and Vampiric Draining don't work on them.
  • They eventually "time out" regardless of their HP, vanishing in a cloud of smoke.
    • Summoned monsters immediately vanish upon the death of their summoner.
    • Most player summons will vanish if angered.
    • They are vulnerable to abjuration and Yara's Violent Unravelling.
  • They will not follow you up or down stairs. This allows you to flee hostile summoned units and return after sufficient time has passed. Your own summoned allies will disappear immediately when you change floors.
  • Allied summons will not attack monsters outside of the player's line of sight.

Duration

Summoned monsters are generated with a duration between 1 and 6. This value roughly corresponds to the following amount in auts (arbitrary units of time; 10 aut = 1 "turn"):[1]

  1. 90 aut
  2. 180 aut
  3. 270 aut
  4. 360 aut
  5. 810 aut
  6. 1710 aut

Some Summonings spells have a fixed duration. Other spells increase duration with power (spellpower, piety, etc.).

Summon Limit

Most Summonings spells have a cap on how many monsters you can sustain at any one time; exceeding the limit will cause the oldest monsters to time out almost immediately. Other sources of summons, like gods, evocables, and the scroll of summoning, are unaffected.

Durable Summon

This monster has been summoned in a durable way, and only partially exists. Killing it yields no experience or items, and it cannot be abjured.

A durable summon, or monster that is durably summoned, is similar to a summoned monster with a few notable exceptions:

  • They never disappear.
  • They are not vulnerable to abjuration or Yara's Violent Unravelling.
  • They will follow you up or down stairs.
  • They can be targeted by Vampiric Draining.

Durable summons are most often used as punishments for the player; whenever from the divine retribution of several gods, or nameless horrors from miscast Summonings spells.

Non-Summons

The following effects are not summoned, despite sharing similarities:

  • Malign Gateway, which is immune to abjuration and will turn hostile over time. This is the only Summonings spell that doesn't create an actual summon.
  • Derived undead, created by Necromancy. They are still temporary when created by the player, vanishing if you enter another floor.
  • Hornets from a shambling mangrove or reinforcements from a doom hound, which are completely non-summons and worth XP and piety as usual.

History

  • Prior to 0.29, Uskayaw did not give piety for harming summoned monsters.
  • Prior to 0.28, summoned monsters would steal XP proportional to their damage dealt (1/2 XP if you did no damage)
  • Prior to 0.25, non-durable summons could not be affected by Inner Flame. In addition, most player-summoned creatures didn't vanish when they became hostile.
  • Prior to 0.19, the mercenary card would create allied durable summons.
  • Prior to 0.18, the warding intrinsic existed to counter (non durable) summons.

References
